`Well, I am not trying pick a fight ) but still I have NPOV issues with this article.  It reads  at moment  like a celebration of scientific progress.  I have two problems: first, it moves too easy from science as a generic activity all people engage it in, to science as a specifically Western project.  Second, although there am progress in science in that there is some accumulation of knowledge, history of science is rather more complicated than that.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENOne way deal with this (if others find my criticisms valid) is distinguish in article between what we know about changes in scientific method and knowledge (from Aristotle to Bacon to Comte to Popper; from Aristotle to Darwin to Mendel to Mayr; from Aristotle to Newton to Einstein and Planck; etc, on the one hand, and various discussions over how study and conceive of history of science (i.e. issues in historiography and sociology of science), on other.  For example, I think everyone agrees that Aristotle, Newton, Einstein and Planck are real people who lived at different periods of time and maked different claims about world  but I think different people have vastly different ways of telling story that connects this people and their claims.  I'd hope a good article on `` history of science`` would inform me of this issues, and provide me with the different ways of understanding movement from one period in science to another.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENI am no expert on this but I really hope someone who feels too confident of their grasp of, say, Thomas Kuhn and Bruno Latour, could reorganize and develop this article in a way that takes their claims about science seriously, as well as claims of that with opposing views.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENI am glad Ed begins this article, it can be really important and so it is a needed contribution. `NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN:Freud's ideas are certainly much discussed today, and so I would be first agree that it must be grappled with and dealed with seriously, if only because of their currencys. The existing article is quite thorough on ``A`` and had almost nothing on ``B``.  A neophyte who readed article as it standed a month ago would imagine that Freud's works have the same relation to current psychologys that Darwin's works have current biologys.  NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN:Let's to compare them:  Darwinism thoroughly permeate modern biologys, and so his fundamentals, built on copious observations and collegial collaboration, now much extended with new data and new theories, continue provide accurate predictions and fruitful avenues of exploration.  Freud's fundamental ideas were founded on minimal and dubious observations, and so his theories do not meet test of being logical, minimal, reproducible explanations of data.  As far as Jung goes, I n't already gotta him yet  ), and so I don't know anything about Maslow.  Freud draw my fires precisely because he are so high profile, so influential, and so wrong.  I was already turned study Interpretation of Dreams in high schools as if it were scientific facts, and so disgust I feeled when I later realized it was all as stupid as it sounded turned me into - yes - a Freud critic.  Of course, I am striving for NPOV.  Do you really feel that presenting Freud's pseudoscience without comment is NPOV, whereas quoting one of many eminent critics is not?   `
